fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.bodyText: Terminally trapped Firefighters spent an hour searching an office block in Willenhall, West Midlands, for a distressed bird, only to find that it was a squawking toucan on a computer screensaver. Express and Star, 6.6.01 (Mary Cooper, Wolverhampton) Reel nuisance The owner of a cinema in Haverfordwest, west Wales, has installed hidden cameras to catch people who use mobile phones during films. Manchester Evening News, 7.6.01 (Jon Booth, Stockport) Singalong service Members of a church in Hucknall, Nottinghamshire, raised £2,850 to buy a hymn-playing karaoke machine after their organist moved out of the area. Church Times, 24.5.01 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea) Distorted view A man walking to work along a canal towpath in Ryeford, Gloucestershire, was surprised by a woman flasher, who lifted up her dress and then ran away. Stroud News and Journal, 6.6.01 (Sue Ptaszek, Uley) Complimentary card A woman from Manchester has sent a thank-you card to scaffolders who wolf-whistled her as she walked down the street on her 60th birthday. Worcestershire Evening Mail, 8.6.01 (Simon Harley, Redditch) Fast bucks A speed camera on the M11 at Woodford, Essex, has been trapping up to 2,000 drivers a day, averaging £5,000 an hour in fines. Metro, 7.6.01 (A Bird, Enfield) Break-in The jammed door of a bank in Newport, Shropshire, finally had to be forced open four hours after staff had arrived for work and found they couldn't get in. Newport Advertiser, 8.6.01 (Beverley Woodhead, Newport) Keeping shtum A couple from Bridlington, Yorkshire, were bemused why the Rottweiler they got from a dogs' home didn't respond to any commands, until they were told that its previous owner was Coventry City's Swedish international goalkeeper Magnus Hedman. Yorkshire Evening Post, 5.6.01 (John Rossington, Bradford) Plummy duff Public announcements on the Midland Metro tram line have been changed after travellers complained that the voice was too posh. Shropshire Star, 29.5.01 (John Simblet, Shrewsbury) Tailback A New Forest pony caused a traffic jam when it began mating with a mare on a busy road near Brockenhurst, Hampshire. Birmingham Evening Mail, 1.6.01 (Simon Briggs, Bearwood) Nutty professors Scientists at Newcastle University are experimenting with running a car on hazelnuts, by using the shells to generate hydrogen to power a fuel cell. Advanced Driving, spring 01 (B Purvis, Winchester) Street's ahead Bereaved relatives from two families were told that funerals could not be held at a cemetery in Salford, Greater Manchester, because it was being used to film an episode of Coronation Street. Birmingham Evening Mail, 30.5.01 (William Benton, Birmingham) Cold comfort A group of Edinburgh University students has designed a temperature-controlled pillow to ease stress and to help people sleep better on hot nights. Daily Post, 30.5.01 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes) Caught unawares Security at Burnley crown court, Lancashire, is being reviewed after an intruder broke into the judges' chambers and stole a laptop computer. Lancashire Evening Telegraph, 28.5.01 (Peter Tapper, Burnley) Cuttings, preferably from local papers, which reflect interesting or amusing aspects of life in Britain, must be sent on a postcard (with source) to: Society, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. £15 will be paid for each one used.
